23.2 log @Update document after refactoring. @ text @<?xml version='1.1' encoding='UTF-8'?> <xwikidoc version="1.3" reference="Allgemein.Hilfestellungen.ROS.ROS GettingStarted.Using the ZED Camera with ROS.WebHome" locale=""> <web>Allgemein.Hilfestellungen.ROS.ROS GettingStarted.Using the ZED Camera with ROS</web> <name>WebHome</name> <language/> <defaultLanguage>en</defaultLanguage> <translation>0</translation> <creator>XWiki.SvenHoyer</creator> <creationDate>1572525427000</creationDate> <parent>Allgemein.Hilfestellungen.ROS.ROS GettingStarted.WebHome</parent> <author>XWiki.SvenHoyer</author> <contentAuthor>XWiki.DavidDudzik</contentAuthor> <date>1572525428000</date> <contentUpdateDate>1572525427000</contentUpdateDate> <version>23.2</version> <title>Using the ZED Camera with ROS</title> <comment>Update document after refactoring.</comment> <minorEdit>true</minorEdit> <syntaxId>xwiki/2.1</syntaxId> <hidden>false</hidden> <content>[[image:zedCameraROS2.png]]
**Sitemap**
----
{{toc start="2"/}}
== Using the ZED Camera with ROS ==
----
The ROS wrapper is an interface between the ZED SDK and the ROS framework. This wrapper lets you access ZED stereo:
* Left and right rectified/unrectified images * Depth map * Colored 3D point cloud * Visual odometry: Position and orientation of the camera * {{warning}}Pose tracking: Position and orientation of the camera fixed and fused with IMU data (ZED Mini only){{/warning}}
in the ROS environment.
== Installation ==
----
You also need to install the ZED SDK with CUDA and OpenCV
(% class="wikigeneratedid" id="HPrerequisites" %) ((( **Downloads** )))
----
* Ubuntu 16.04 * ZED SDK for Download klick [[here>>https://www.stereolabs.com/developers/release/]] * CUDA 10.0 for Download klick [[here>>https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads]] * ROS Kinetic
**Installing the SDK**
----
Unpack your camera, plug the camera in a USB 3.0 port and go to the next step.
On Linux, download the ZED SDK or Linux and launch the .run file from a terminal.
{{code}} chmod +x ZED_SDK_Linux_*.run ./ZED_SDK_Linux_*.run
{{/code}}
* **Restart** you computer to complete the installation. * After the installation, download CUDA
=== Build the package ===
----
**zed_ros_wrapper** is a catkin package. It depends on the following ROS packages:
* tf2_ros * tf2_geometry_msgs * nav_msgs * roscpp * rosconsole * sensor_msgs * stereo_msgs * image_transport * dynamic_reconfigure * nodelet
you can check this in ROS with
{{code}} $ rospack find <package name>
{{/code}}
for example :
{{code}} $ rospack find nodelet
{{/code}}
To install **zed_ros_wrapper**, open a bash terminal, clone the package from Github and build it:
{{code}} cd ~/catkin_ws/src git clone https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper.git cd ../ catkin_make source ./devel/setup.bash {{/code}}
**Note:** If you are using a different console interface like zsh, you have to change the source command as follows: echo source $(pwd)/devel/setup.zsh >> ~~/.zshrc and source ~~/.zshrc.
== Getting Started with ROS ==
=== Starting the ZED node ===
----
The ZED is available in ROS as a node that publishes its data to Topics.
You can read the full list of available topics [[here>>https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]].
Open a terminal and use roslaunch to start the ZED node:
{{code}} $ roslaunch zed_wrapper zed.launch {{/code}}
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** You can set your own configuration parameters in the **zed_camera.launch** file available [[here>>https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper/blob/master/zed_wrapper/launch/zed_camera.launch]] )))
== Displaying ==
=== Displaying ZED data ===
----
=== ===
**Using RVIZ**
RVIZ is a useful visualization tool in ROS.
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** If you haven’t yet configured your own RVIZ interface, you can find a detailed tutorial [[here>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/rviz/]]. )))
Launch the ZED wrapper along with RVIZ using the following command:
{{code}} $ roslaunch zed_display_rviz display.launch {{/code}}
=== Displaying Images ===
----
The ZED node publishes both original and stereo rectified (aligned) left and right images. In RVIZ, select a topic you and use the image preview mode. Here the list of the available image topics:
{{code}} zed/rgb/image_rect_color: Color rectified image (left image by default) zed/rgb/image_raw_color: Color unrectified image (left image by default) zed/rgb/camera_info: Left camera calibration data zed/right/image_rect_color: Color rectified right image zed/right/image_raw_color: Color unrectified right image zed/right/camera_info: Right sensor calibration data zed/confidence/confidence_image: Confidence map as image {{/code}}
((( (% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** The Confidence Map is also available as a 32bit floating point image subscribing to the **/zed/confidence/confidence_map** topic. )))
=== ===
=== Displaying Depth ===
----
The depth map can be displayed in RVIZ with the following topic:
**zed/depth/depth_registered**:
32-bit depth values in meters. RVIZ will normalize the depth map on 8-bit and display it as a grayscale depth image.
**Note:** An OpenNI compatibility mode is available in the launch/zed_camera.launch file. Set openni_depth_mode to 1 to get depth in millimeters and in 16-bit precision, and restart the ZED node.
=== Displaying Disparity ===
----
The Disparity Image is available by subscribing to the **zed/disparity/disparity_image** topics.
Launch the Disparity Viewer to visualize it:
{{code}} $ rosrun image_view disparity_view image:=/zed/disparity/disparity_image {{/code}} )))
=== ===
=== Displaying the Point cloud ===
----
A 3D colored point cloud can be displayed in RVIZ with the
**zed/point_cloud/cloud_registered** topic.
Add it in RVIZ with **point_cloud** -> **cloud** -> **PointCloud2**.
Note that displaying point clouds slows down RVIZ, so open a new instance if you want to display other topics
=== Displaying position and path ===
----
The ZED position and orientation in space over time is published to the following topics:
* **zed/odom**: Odometry pose referred to odometry frame (only visual odometry is applied for ZED, visual-inertial for ZED Mini) * **zed/pose**: Camera pose referred to Map frame (complete data fusion algorithm is applied) * **zed/pose_with_covariance**: Camera pose referred to Map frame with covariance (if spatial_memory is false in launch parameters) * **zed/path_odom**: The sequence of camera odometry poses in Map frame * **zed/path_map**: The sequence of camera poses in Map frame
**Important:** By default, RVIZ does not display odometry data correctly. Open the newly created **Odometry** object in the left list, and set **Position Tolerance** and **Angle Tolerance** to **0**, and **Keep** to**1**.
== Launching with recorded SVO video ==
----
With the ZED, you can record and play back stereo video using the .svo file format. To record a sequence, open the ZED Explorer app and click on the **REC** button.
To launch the ROS wrapper with an SVO file, set an **svo_file** path [[launch parameter>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]] in the command line when starting the package:
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Important:** Use only full paths to the SVO file. Relative paths are not allowed. )))
== Dynamic reconfigure ==
----
You can dynamically change many configuration parameters during the execution of the ZED node:
* **confidence threshold**: Sets a threshold that filters the values of the depth or the point cloud. With a //confidence threshold// set to 100, all depth values will be written in the depth and the point cloud. This is set to 80 by default, which removes the least accurate values. * **auto_exposure**: Enables/disables automatic gain and exposure * **exposure**: Sets camera exposure only if //auto_exposure// is false * **gain**: Set camera gain only if //auto_exposure// is false * **mat_resize_factor**: Sets the scale factor of the output images and depth map. Note that the camera will acquire data at the dimension set by the //resolution// parameter; images are resized before being sent to the user * **max_depth**: Sets the maximum depth range
You can set the parameters using the command //dynparam set//, e.g.:
{{code}} $ rosrun dynamic_reconfigure dynparam set /zed/zed_wrapper_node confidence 80 {{/code}}
…or you can use the GUI provided by the rqt stack:
{{code}} $ rosrun rqt_reconfigure rqt_reconfigure {{/code}}

RVIZ is a useful visualization tool in ROS.
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** If you haven’t yet configured your own RVIZ interface, you can find a detailed tutorial [[here>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/rviz/]]. )))
Launch the ZED wrapper along with RVIZ using the following command:
{{code}} $ roslaunch zed_display_rviz display.launch {{/code}}
=== Displaying Images ===
----
The ZED node publishes both original and stereo rectified (aligned) left and right images. In RVIZ, select a topic you and use the image preview mode. Here the list of the available image topics:
{{code}} zed/rgb/image_rect_color: Color rectified image (left image by default) zed/rgb/image_raw_color: Color unrectified image (left image by default) zed/rgb/camera_info: Left camera calibration data zed/right/image_rect_color: Color rectified right image zed/right/image_raw_color: Color unrectified right image zed/right/camera_info: Right sensor calibration data zed/confidence/confidence_image: Confidence map as image {{/code}}
((( (% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** The Confidence Map is also available as a 32bit floating point image subscribing to the **/zed/confidence/confidence_map** topic. )))
=== ===
=== Displaying Depth ===
----
The depth map can be displayed in RVIZ with the following topic:
**zed/depth/depth_registered**:
32-bit depth values in meters. RVIZ will normalize the depth map on 8-bit and display it as a grayscale depth image.
**Note:** An OpenNI compatibility mode is available in the launch/zed_camera.launch file. Set openni_depth_mode to 1 to get depth in millimeters and in 16-bit precision, and restart the ZED node.
=== Displaying Disparity ===
----
The Disparity Image is available by subscribing to the **zed/disparity/disparity_image** topics.
Launch the Disparity Viewer to visualize it:
{{code}} $ rosrun image_view disparity_view image:=/zed/disparity/disparity_image {{/code}} )))
=== ===
=== Displaying the Point cloud ===
----
A 3D colored point cloud can be displayed in RVIZ with the
**zed/point_cloud/cloud_registered** topic.
Add it in RVIZ with **point_cloud** -> **cloud** -> **PointCloud2**.
Note that displaying point clouds slows down RVIZ, so open a new instance if you want to display other topics
=== Displaying position and path ===
----
The ZED position and orientation in space over time is published to the following topics:
* **zed/odom**: Odometry pose referred to odometry frame (only visual odometry is applied for ZED, visual-inertial for ZED Mini) * **zed/pose**: Camera pose referred to Map frame (complete data fusion algorithm is applied) * **zed/pose_with_covariance**: Camera pose referred to Map frame with covariance (if spatial_memory is false in launch parameters) * **zed/path_odom**: The sequence of camera odometry poses in Map frame * **zed/path_map**: The sequence of camera poses in Map frame
**Important:** By default, RVIZ does not display odometry data correctly. Open the newly created **Odometry** object in the left list, and set **Position Tolerance** and **Angle Tolerance** to **0**, and **Keep** to**1**.
== Launching with recorded SVO video ==
----
With the ZED, you can record and play back stereo video using the .svo file format. To record a sequence, open the ZED Explorer app and click on the **REC** button.
To launch the ROS wrapper with an SVO file, set an **svo_file** path [[launch parameter>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]] in the command line when starting the package:
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Important:** Use only full paths to the SVO file. Relative paths are not allowed. )))
== Dynamic reconfigure ==
----
You can dynamically change many configuration parameters during the execution of the ZED node:
* **confidence threshold**: Sets a threshold that filters the values of the depth or the point cloud. With a //confidence threshold// set to 100, all depth values will be written in the depth and the point cloud. This is set to 80 by default, which removes the least accurate values. * **auto_exposure**: Enables/disables automatic gain and exposure * **exposure**: Sets camera exposure only if //auto_exposure// is false * **gain**: Set camera gain only if //auto_exposure// is false * **mat_resize_factor**: Sets the scale factor of the output images and depth map. Note that the camera will acquire data at the dimension set by the //resolution// parameter; images are resized before being sent to the user * **max_depth**: Sets the maximum depth range
You can set the parameters using the command //dynparam set//, e.g.:
{{code}} $ rosrun dynamic_reconfigure dynparam set /zed/zed_wrapper_node confidence 80 {{/code}}
…or you can use the GUI provided by the rqt stack:
{{code}} $ rosrun rqt_reconfigure rqt_reconfigure {{/code}}
[[image:image-20190228133706-1.png||height="291" width="672"]]

**Sitemap**
----
{{toc start="2"/}}
== Using the ZED Camera with ROS ==
----
The ROS wrapper is an interface between the ZED SDK and the ROS framework. This wrapper lets you access ZED stereo:
* Left and right rectified/unrectified images * Depth map * Colored 3D point cloud * Visual odometry: Position and orientation of the camera * {{warning}}Pose tracking: Position and orientation of the camera fixed and fused with IMU data (ZED Mini only){{/warning}}
in the ROS environment.
== Installation ==
----
You also need to install the ZED SDK with CUDA and OpenCV
(% class="wikigeneratedid" id="HPrerequisites" %) ((( **Prerequisites** )))
----
* Ubuntu 16.04 * ZED SDK for Download klick [[here>>https://www.stereolabs.com/developers/release/]] * CUDA for Download klick [[here>>https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads]] * ROS Kinetic
=== Build the package ===
----
**zed_ros_wrapper** is a catkin package. It depends on the following ROS packages:
* tf2_ros * tf2_geometry_msgs * nav_msgs * roscpp * rosconsole * sensor_msgs * stereo_msgs * image_transport * dynamic_reconfigure * nodelet
you can check this in ROS with
{{code}} $ rospack find <package name>
{{/code}}
for example :
{{code}} $ rospack find nodelet
{{/code}}
To install **zed_ros_wrapper**, open a bash terminal, clone the package from Github and build it:
{{code}} $ cd ~/catkin_ws/src/ #use your current catkin folder $ git clone https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper.git $ cd .. $ catkin_make -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release $ echo source $(pwd)/devel/setup.bash >> ~/.bashrc $ source ~/.bashrc {{/code}}
**Note:** If you are using a different console interface like zsh, you have to change the source command as follows: echo source $(pwd)/devel/setup.zsh >> ~~/.zshrc and source ~~/.zshrc.
== Getting Started with ROS ==
=== Starting the ZED node ===
----
The ZED is available in ROS as a node that publishes its data to Topics.
You can read the full list of available topics [[here>>https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]].
Open a terminal and use roslaunch to start the ZED node:
{{code}} $ roslaunch zed_wrapper zed.launch {{/code}}
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** You can set your own configuration parameters in the **zed_camera.launch** file available [[here>>https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper/blob/master/zed_wrapper/launch/zed_camera.launch]] )))
== Displaying ==

=== ===

=== ===

**Important:** By default, RVIZ does not display odometry data correctly. Open the newly created **Odometry** object in the left list, and set **Position Tolerance** and **Angle Tolerance** to **0**, and **Keep** to**1**.
== Launching with recorded SVO video ==
----
With the ZED, you can record and play back stereo video using the .svo file format. To record a sequence, open the ZED Explorer app and click on the **REC** button.
To launch the ROS wrapper with an SVO file, set an **svo_file** path [[launch parameter>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]] in the command line when starting the package:

**Sitemap**
----
{{toc start="2"/}}
== Using the ZED Camera with ROS ==
----
The ROS wrapper is an interface between the ZED SDK and the ROS framework. This wrapper lets you access ZED stereo:
* Left and right rectified/unrectified images * Depth map * Colored 3D point cloud * Visual odometry: Position and orientation of the camera * {{warning}}Pose tracking: Position and orientation of the camera fixed and fused with IMU data (ZED Mini only){{/warning}}
in the ROS environment.
== Installation ==
----
You also need to install the ZED SDK with CUDA and OpenCV
(% class="wikigeneratedid" id="HPrerequisites" %) ((( **Prerequisites** )))
----
* Ubuntu 16.04 * ZED SDK for Download klick [[hier>>https://www.stereolabs.com/developers/release/]] * CUDA for Download klick [[hier>>https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads]] * ROS Kinetic
=== Build the package ===
----
**zed_ros_wrapper** is a catkin package. It depends on the following ROS packages:
* tf2_ros * tf2_geometry_msgs * nav_msgs * roscpp * rosconsole * sensor_msgs * stereo_msgs * image_transport * dynamic_reconfigure * nodelet
you can check this in ROS with
{{code}} $ rospack find <package name>
{{/code}}
for example :
{{code}} $ rospack find nodelet
{{/code}}
To install **zed_ros_wrapper**, open a bash terminal, clone the package from Github and build it:
{{code}} $ cd ~/catkin_ws/src/ #use your current catkin folder $ git clone https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper.git $ cd .. $ catkin_make -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release $ echo source $(pwd)/devel/setup.bash >> ~/.bashrc $ source ~/.bashrc {{/code}}</content> <attachment> <filename>zedCameraROS2.png</filename> <author>XWiki.DavidDudzik</author> <date>1550757161000</date> <version>1.1</version> <comment/> <filesize>3714</filesize> </attachment> </xwikidoc>@

xwikidoc.title: Using the ZED Camera with ROS
xwikidoc.content:
[[image:zedCameraROS2.png]]
**Sitemap**
----
{{toc start="2"/}}
== Using the ZED Camera with ROS ==
----
The ROS wrapper is an interface between the ZED SDK and the ROS framework. This wrapper lets you access ZED stereo:
* Left and right rectified/unrectified images * Depth map * Colored 3D point cloud * Visual odometry: Position and orientation of the camera * {{warning}}Pose tracking: Position and orientation of the camera fixed and fused with IMU data (ZED Mini only){{/warning}}
in the ROS environment.
== Installation ==
----
You also need to install the ZED SDK with CUDA and OpenCV
(% class="wikigeneratedid" id="HPrerequisites" %) ((( **Downloads** )))
----
* Ubuntu 16.04 * ZED SDK for Download klick [[here>>https://www.stereolabs.com/developers/release/]] * CUDA 10.0 for Download klick [[here>>https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads]] * ROS Kinetic
**Installing the SDK**
----
Unpack your camera, plug the camera in a USB 3.0 port and go to the next step.
On Linux, download the ZED SDK or Linux and launch the .run file from a terminal.
{{code}} chmod +x ZED_SDK_Linux_*.run ./ZED_SDK_Linux_*.run
{{/code}}
* **Restart** you computer to complete the installation. * After the installation, download CUDA
=== Build the package ===
----
**zed_ros_wrapper** is a catkin package. It depends on the following ROS packages:
* tf2_ros * tf2_geometry_msgs * nav_msgs * roscpp * rosconsole * sensor_msgs * stereo_msgs * image_transport * dynamic_reconfigure * nodelet
you can check this in ROS with
{{code}} $ rospack find <package name>
{{/code}}
for example :
{{code}} $ rospack find nodelet
{{/code}}
To install **zed_ros_wrapper**, open a bash terminal, clone the package from Github and build it:
{{code}} cd ~/catkin_ws/src git clone https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper.git cd ../ catkin_make source ./devel/setup.bash {{/code}}
**Note:** If you are using a different console interface like zsh, you have to change the source command as follows: echo source $(pwd)/devel/setup.zsh >> ~~/.zshrc and source ~~/.zshrc.
== Getting Started with ROS ==
=== Starting the ZED node ===
----
The ZED is available in ROS as a node that publishes its data to Topics.
You can read the full list of available topics [[here>>https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]].
Open a terminal and use roslaunch to start the ZED node:
{{code}} $ roslaunch zed_wrapper zed.launch {{/code}}
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** You can set your own configuration parameters in the **zed_camera.launch** file available [[here>>https://github.com/stereolabs/zed-ros-wrapper/blob/master/zed_wrapper/launch/zed_camera.launch]] )))
== Displaying ==
=== Displaying ZED data ===
----
=== ===
**Using RVIZ**
RVIZ is a useful visualization tool in ROS.
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** If you haven’t yet configured your own RVIZ interface, you can find a detailed tutorial [[here>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/rviz/]]. )))
Launch the ZED wrapper along with RVIZ using the following command:
{{code}} $ roslaunch zed_display_rviz display.launch {{/code}}
=== Displaying Images ===
----
The ZED node publishes both original and stereo rectified (aligned) left and right images. In RVIZ, select a topic you and use the image preview mode. Here the list of the available image topics:
{{code}} zed/rgb/image_rect_color: Color rectified image (left image by default) zed/rgb/image_raw_color: Color unrectified image (left image by default) zed/rgb/camera_info: Left camera calibration data zed/right/image_rect_color: Color rectified right image zed/right/image_raw_color: Color unrectified right image zed/right/camera_info: Right sensor calibration data zed/confidence/confidence_image: Confidence map as image {{/code}}
((( (% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Note:** The Confidence Map is also available as a 32bit floating point image subscribing to the **/zed/confidence/confidence_map** topic. )))
=== ===
=== Displaying Depth ===
----
The depth map can be displayed in RVIZ with the following topic:
**zed/depth/depth_registered**:
32-bit depth values in meters. RVIZ will normalize the depth map on 8-bit and display it as a grayscale depth image.
**Note:** An OpenNI compatibility mode is available in the launch/zed_camera.launch file. Set openni_depth_mode to 1 to get depth in millimeters and in 16-bit precision, and restart the ZED node.
=== Displaying Disparity ===
----
The Disparity Image is available by subscribing to the **zed/disparity/disparity_image** topics.
Launch the Disparity Viewer to visualize it:
{{code}} $ rosrun image_view disparity_view image:=/zed/disparity/disparity_image {{/code}} )))
=== ===
=== Displaying the Point cloud ===
----
A 3D colored point cloud can be displayed in RVIZ with the
**zed/point_cloud/cloud_registered** topic.
Add it in RVIZ with **point_cloud** -> **cloud** -> **PointCloud2**.
Note that displaying point clouds slows down RVIZ, so open a new instance if you want to display other topics
=== Displaying position and path ===
----
The ZED position and orientation in space over time is published to the following topics:
* **zed/odom**: Odometry pose referred to odometry frame (only visual odometry is applied for ZED, visual-inertial for ZED Mini) * **zed/pose**: Camera pose referred to Map frame (complete data fusion algorithm is applied) * **zed/pose_with_covariance**: Camera pose referred to Map frame with covariance (if spatial_memory is false in launch parameters) * **zed/path_odom**: The sequence of camera odometry poses in Map frame * **zed/path_map**: The sequence of camera poses in Map frame
**Important:** By default, RVIZ does not display odometry data correctly. Open the newly created **Odometry** object in the left list, and set **Position Tolerance** and **Angle Tolerance** to **0**, and **Keep** to**1**.
== Launching with recorded SVO video ==
----
With the ZED, you can record and play back stereo video using the .svo file format. To record a sequence, open the ZED Explorer app and click on the **REC** button.
To launch the ROS wrapper with an SVO file, set an **svo_file** path [[launch parameter>>url:https://www.stereolabs.com/docs/ros/zed_node/]] in the command line when starting the package:
(% class="box infomessage" %) ((( **Important:** Use only full paths to the SVO file. Relative paths are not allowed. )))
== Dynamic reconfigure ==
----
You can dynamically change many configuration parameters during the execution of the ZED node:
* **confidence threshold**: Sets a threshold that filters the values of the depth or the point cloud. With a //confidence threshold// set to 100, all depth values will be written in the depth and the point cloud. This is set to 80 by default, which removes the least accurate values. * **auto_exposure**: Enables/disables automatic gain and exposure * **exposure**: Sets camera exposure only if //auto_exposure// is false * **gain**: Set camera gain only if //auto_exposure// is false * **mat_resize_factor**: Sets the scale factor of the output images and depth map. Note that the camera will acquire data at the dimension set by the //resolution// parameter; images are resized before being sent to the user * **max_depth**: Sets the maximum depth range
You can set the parameters using the command //dynparam set//, e.g.:
{{code}} $ rosrun dynamic_reconfigure dynparam set /zed/zed_wrapper_node confidence 80 {{/code}}
…or you can use the GUI provided by the rqt stack:
{{code}} $ rosrun rqt_reconfigure rqt_reconfigure {{/code}}
[[image:image-20190228133706-1.png||height="291" width="672"]]
